result.markdown:
:::: {.content-hidden when-format="revealjs"} ## A brief introduction to Quatro is a unified authoring framework that allows for the integration of code, written material and a wide variety of interactive visual formats into one publishable finished document. #### Quarto allows you to: - Create dynamic content that is updated as your code changes - Numerous thematic settings for high quality formatting including 'Pandoc' markdown support for equations and cross-referencing - Publish your work as websites or books - Edit with any text editor including VS Code, RStudio and more ### Some of the creative ways in which you can use Quarto is: #### 1. Visualize and publish interactive plots using html widgets ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(ggplot2) library(plotly) p <- ggplot(data = diamonds, aes(x = cut, fill = clarity)) + geom_bar(position = "dodge") ggplotly(p) ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-error} ``` Error in train(..., self = self): unused argument (list("cut", "clarity", "count", "weight")) ``` ::: ::: #### 2. Create interactive geo-spatial mapping segments ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} library(leaflet) leaflet() %>% addTiles() %>% # Add default OpenStreetMap map tiles addMarkers(lng= 8.548, lat=47.376, popup="ETH") ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: #### 3. Create multi-purpose dashboards to demostrate your research output ![](https://quarto.org/docs/dashboards/examples/thumbnails/customer-churn-dashboard.png){width=60% fig-align="center"} ::: ::: {.content-visible when-format="revealjs"} :::
